title: Scottish Ghost Stories
author: O'Donnell, Elliott
snippet: Another servant at the house, of the name of Jenny Blackadder, usedconstantly to hear Jean, but could never see her--though her husbanddid.

title: Hunted and Harried
author: Ballantyne, R. M. (Robert Michael)
snippet: Some of the ejected ministers, such asBlackadder and Welsh, professed to be undecided on this point, and leantto a more or less submissive course.

title: Hunted and Harried
author: Ballantyne, R. M. (Robert Michael)
snippet: Besides John Welsh of Irongray,there were Arnot of Tongland, Blackadder of Troqueer, and Dickson ofRutherglen--godly men who had for many years suffered persecution andimprisonment, and were ready to lay down their lives in defence ofreligious liberty.

title: Hunted and Harried
author: Ballantyne, R. M. (Robert Michael)
snippet: Preliminary services, conducted by Mr. Blackadder and Mr. Welsh, wereheld near Dumfries on the Saturday, but at these the place of meeting onthe Sabbath was only vaguely announced as "a hillside in Irongray," soanxious were they to escape being disturbed by their enemies, and thesecret was kept so well that when the Sabbath arrived a congregation ofabove three thousand had assembled round the Communion stones in thehollow of Skeoch Hill.

title: Hunted and Harried
author: Ballantyne, R. M. (Robert Michael)
snippet: The Reverend John Blackadder, the "auld" minister ofTroqueer--a noted hero of the Covenant, who afterwards died a prisoneron the Bass Rock--travelled with his party all the way from Edinburgh,and a company of eighty horse proceeded to the meeting from Clydesdale.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: " Were you at Mrs. Blackadder's ? " asked Katie.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: '^ Eh, Mistress, Mr. Blackadder's a man in his prime ! " cried Marget.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: There's nae such stock in the country as the beasts that are reared at Tyneside ; and I mean to take a leaf out of Mr. Blackadder' s book, if I'm spared, and see what we can do at Norlaw."

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: Like the driven cloud, they fly without a sound along the gloomy avenue pursuers and pursued, their swords flashing and their hell- forged harness glinting, as they sweep like shadows oure the dewy grass, with the stars shining through the ribs of their skeleton horses, till the spirit of Blackadder plunges into the loch, as it did on his dying day then red flash their petronels,  and the pure water sparkles around them like diamonds in the moonlight an eldritch yell arises from its shining bosom, and all is over ! "

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Now shall ye behold the spirits of the dead, that many a time and oft on this returning night, I have seen rush forth from yonder woods, Sir Patrick of Blackadder, and his slayers, Douglas, Hume, and Clermistonlee.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: " The vaults are gey far doon we would be deeved wi' him else," replied the gudeman ; " but he gangs to the Bass in the morning, and there he can sing psalmody to the roaring waves and the cauld east wind, wi' Traill, Bennet, Blackadder, and other brethren in tribulation."
